vulnerability_information:
Hi Team, 
I observe a strange behaviour in your registration form. When we are making account and entering the first and last name. According to security concerns you should force user to write their first and last names which actually looks like name for example your should force users that the first and last name should be alphabets like "Husnain Iqbal" It cant be a number or email. 
I noticed that in other websites show error if you written a number or email in first name or last name. 
so the thing is you also should error when a user enter a number or email in first name and last name for security reasons.

Reproduce steps: 
1. Go to registration Form 
2. Fill first name with 101001010 or hi101@gmail.com and last name like 101011991 or hi102@gmail.com 
3. Then fill the other fields of the registration form . 
4. Then click register and the account will successfully made. 

Poc: 

For Proof of concept i am attaching some screen shots. you can look at it.

Recommendation: 

Account Name Cant be numbers or email for security purposes. If a user enters an email in his name by which he/she is getting registered so it is easy for hacker to compromise the account.
title: Name can't be numbers or email

activities.message:
Thanks for the report. We actually allow people to use strange characters or numbers in their names because it is possible for their legal name to contain unusual characters. In fact, while it baffles me why someone would do this, you can actually legally change your name to a URL in some places. Not just like Kim Dotcom, but an actual URL. In 2003, a PETA activist named Karin Robertson [changed her legal name](http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/tech/webguide/internetlife/2003-08-01-goveg_x.htm) to `GoVeg.com`.

As I mentioned in report #254927 (publicly disclosed), there is no demonstrable security risk from allowing a user to enter their first name as something containing numbers or even special characters like `><)))*> I ♡ sushi`. Obviously, this is not what we anticipate from most users, but people have certainly changed their legal names to unusual things like `Goveg.com` or `"The" Dan Miller Experience` (really... including the quotes). Alas, we should allow those people to benefit from our service and sign up with their legal names :-)
activities.markdown_message:
Thanks for the report. We actually allow people to use strange characters or numbers in their names because it is possible for their legal name to contain unusual characters. In fact, while it baffles me why someone would do this, you can actually legally change your name to a URL in some places. Not just like Kim Dotcom, but an actual URL. In 2003, a PETA activist named Karin Robertson changed her legal name to GoVeg.com.

As I mentioned in report #254927 (publicly disclosed), there is no demonstrable security risk from allowing a user to enter their first name as something containing numbers or even special characters like ><)))*> I ♡ sushi. Obviously, this is not what we anticipate from most users, but people have certainly changed their legal names to unusual things like Goveg.com or "The" Dan Miller Experience (really... including the quotes). Alas, we should allow those people to benefit from our service and sign up with their legal names :-)

activities.message:
No @danrubins you dont get my point as per security rules how you can use an email format in your name field. Mostly websites when you are making an account if you enter email format in name field they will show you error like please enter a valid name or something like that. For example if your fill your name with hi101@gmail.com it will make your account with this. see the second screen shot which i sended to you. Email cant be used in name field. 
Sending you some more screenshots in which you can see clearly if name can be proceed like email then whats the different between email functaionality. This is the authentication Flaw. Review it again @danrubins .And see screenshots too.
Thanks

activities.message: I am not saying about special characters i am saying a totally different thing how anyone can be able to make an account Name with like "hi1011@gmail.com" Its look like an email. It cant be used as a name as per security purposes. I hope you understand @danrubins
activities.markdown_message: I am not saying about special characters i am saying a totally different thing how anyone can be able to make an account Name with like "hi1011@gmail.com" Its look like an email. It cant be used as a name as per security purposes. I hope you understand @danrubins

activities.message:
Yes, I understand that. I just bring up the special characters to illustrate how, just as one could use a URL in their name, it would be legally feasible to use an email in their name. Presumably, someone who changed their name to an email would want to then *use* that email, so a direct match is also acceptable.

Obviously, this is totally an edge case and there is some incremental risk of misidentifying another user based on their name, which could look like an email (e.g. you could set your first name to hello@legalrobot.com). However, when looking up other users we have ways to show validated information (this feature is still in beta).

activities.message:
First off, thanks, I truly appreciate the dialogue. Sometimes our team (especially me!) gets things wrong and it's only through dialogue like this that we figure that out. In this case, what I'm saying is that, yes, there is some risk there of misidentifying another user that has set their name to something odd (even to "Legal Robot") but we're accepting that risk and mitigating it in other ways. Many other services do not accept that risk, but some do (e.g. parody accounts on Twitter).

To your question: the main difference between the name fields and email is that we don't use the name fields programmatically, it's really only for display. So, the main risk is to other users and whether other users could mistake an account for one they trust. For that risk, we mitigate it by human verification of a user's information before they are allowed to take certain actions (like create a Team), and for user-to-user actions, with a pop-up that very clearly shows the email separate from the name fields (see attachment). Note: this feature is still in beta, we don't actually allow most users to connect at this time.

I observe a strange behaviour in your registration form. When we are making account and entering the first and last name. According to security concerns you should force user to write their first and last names which actually looks like name for example your should force users that the first and last name should be alphabets like "Husnain Iqbal" It cant be a number or email.
I noticed that in other websites show error if you written a number or email in first name or last name.
so the thing is you also should error when a user enter a number or email in first name and last name for security reasons.
